source.df83160a:
sum_male = (about_me.CO10 == '1').sum()
sum_female = (about_me.CO10 == '2').sum()
sum_other = (about_me.CO10 == '3').sum()
sum_all = about_me.CO10.count()

data = {'Males': sum_male, 'Females': sum_female, 'other': sum_other}
names = list(data.keys())
values = list(data.values())

plt.bar(names, values)

print("In Percent:")
print((sum_male/sum_all*100))
print((sum_female/sum_all*100))
print((sum_other/sum_all*100))

it = 0
politics = 0

media = 0

archi = 0
law = 0
lingu = 0
other = 0
no_ans = 0

for i in range(0, len(about_me)):
    if about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "1":
        it += 1
    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "2":
        politics += 1
    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "3":
        psych += 1
    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "4":

    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "5":

    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "6":

    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "7":
        engineering_chem += 1
    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "8":

    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "9":

    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "10":
        law += 1    
    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "11":
        lingu += 1
    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "12":

    elif about_me.iloc[i]['CO07'] == "-9":
        no_ans += 1    
        
data1 = {'IT': it, 'Politics': politics, 'Psychology': psych, 'Business': business, 
         'Design & Art': design_art, 'Media Studies': media, 'Engineering, Chemistry': engineering_chem,
         'Medicine, Biology, Ecology': med_bio, 'Architecture': archi, 'Law': law, 
         'Linguistics Literature': lingu, 'Other': other}

values = list(data1.values())

source.00c4e331: People who marked "other" mainly reported, that classes are only online and campus is closed at all time.
source.a3a9374b:
![asd.png](attachment:asd.png)

**2    Online classes are just as good for student-lecturer interaction as contact classes**

In this evaluation, it was found that online lectures are not well received in Italy.
The practical form of lectures is preferred there.
This could possibly be due to the wrong technology and software, or the students miss the personal contact with the other students and lecturers.
A solution to this problem would be, for example, the introduction of new software that makes learning more interactive.


The motivation of 84 people has decreased rapidly due to the online lectures. The majority of respondents are not so impressed by the online lectures. 
It can be concluded from this that the majority of respondents prefer the classic lecture variant. 

Reasons:
The reasons for this could be related to the fact that students lack contact and interaction with other students. Which has already crystallized somewhat from the previous answers. See answers CB 12 Online lectures/classes suit me better than contact classes.  Online classes are just as good for student-lecturer interaction as contact classes.

Another reason why online lectures are not so well received could be the change to online seminars, both for the students and the lecturers. 

Solutions:  
To counteract this, it would be possible to introduce hybrid lectures.
Where some of the students participate online and the others are physically present. 
Another solution would be to make the online courses more interactive, which would encourage students to communicate with each other.







It is easier to organize group projects when meeting classmates physically.

Finding: 81 people found it easier to organize group projects on a personal level. This study shows once again that students in Italy find it more difficult to adapt to the online world (processes/world).
Problem: Possibly unfamiliar situation or difficulties in the transition. 
Solution: Probably it needs there, a little more time until the Italians have adjusted to this situation.  Possibly it could have cultural backgrounds, why the whole on-line procedure is more difficult for them. The Italians are known for their intercultural communication among each other is somewhat (more pronounced / more passionate). This is something that is lost in the online world (lectures) and some things are lost, such as the typical gesticulation with the hands.
source.83c1b40a:
**3 Online classes where students do the reading at home and work on assignments or projects in class are more effective. **

Finding : The majority of the lecturers disagree with the whole.  
Problem : Workflow/ completion of assignments/projects, assignments, etc.  Have not become more effective through the online courses.  This is confirmed by the previous surveys that the students do not like the online courses.  Comparison of questions CB13 and CB14.
Possibly the lack of willingness of the lecturers to work with e-learning.

Solution: Interactive collaboration in small groups, where students feel encouraged to participate instead of disappearing into the silent masses.

source.61449845: # Infrastructure and Digital Skills under Covid-19
source.d9f29b96:
**CE01**

Issue: Since teaching depends on technology, the university must provide all students with the same resources of laptops and a workspace - otherwise social class and wealth open a gap between people who have them and students who do not.
The same goes for licenses: cost and provision of a PC that can run the program.
source.4b3fb762:
# Structure

The purpose of the survey is to find out, how students perceived the reactions and situation with university and academia in times of covid.
We split the survey into:

* Health & Wellbeing 
* Learning & Teaching Experience
* Communication
* University Services
* Infrastructure & Digital Skills

In addition to that, we collected meta data like sex, age, major etc. to get an overall overview of our participants.
We also provided some information abour the differences between germany and italy, as we collected primarily data from italy while our main audience
is in germany.
source.7d37f888: We upload the data as .csv and pick out the first section of interest we want to manipulate - the About Me Questions:
source.701992c9:
**1   I feel connected to other students – same as under normal conditions.**

Evaluation : 86 out of 110 respondents ( 78%) do not feel more connected to other students through the online lectures as they do under normal operations. 

Problem: Italian students miss being with each other and communicating with other students and lecturers. Which may have a negative impact on their studies.
From this and many other responses, a pattern can be seen that online courses and e-learning are not well received by Italian hours. 

Cause: many students and lecturers in Italy may have problems with the changeover, e-learning was a bit more difficult for some.

Help/recommendation/solution: One solution would be to make the lectures more interactive with a virtual 3D classroom or hybrid lectures, where everyone can freely decide whether they prefer to participate online or with attendance.


**4   Even under Corona, communication on exam matters is fair, transparent and clear.**

Evaluation : 56 people disagree and 54 people feel that communication on audit matters is fair, transparent and clear, even among Corona operators. A 50/50 issue.

Problem : How is it possible to create a fair, transparent and clear communication in exam matters for all. 

Cause : One possible cause would be that most of the exams were oral online, see survey ........// This raises the question, is the oral exam form also applicable to every module. 

Help/recommendation/solution: Here the universities would have to research the reason why the communication is not fair and clear for all students.   
Again, a survey could be started to get feedback from students on where improvement is needed to make communication fair and clear for most students.  From these results one could send out information brochures or hold information seminars and thus provide more clarity.  Not every student has the digital equipment and network connection to stay up to date online.


**4  labs are closed or difficuld to access and 5 no campus events**

Evaluation : For 72 (65%) of students, classrooms and labs remained closed or were difficult to access. For 76% of the respondents, events and lectures were no longer held on campus.

Problem : Students and faculty do not have classrooms where you can teach and learn. Some study modules/subjects cannot be taught under online operation, they are very practical and need the appropriate equipment.

Help/recommendation/solution: One recommendation would be that the universities modify their teaching rooms to comply with hygiene regulations.
Another possibility would be that a certain number of students can use the laboratories or the equipment for a fixed period of time.  With registration and limited number to comply with the hygiene regulations.
source.42196418:
# **Introduction**

Hello and welcome to our Covid-19 Notebook. This Notebook was made in the process of a course "Englisch für Wirtschaftsinformatiker"
in the University of Applied Science in Bielefeld. Directed by Prof Kleinheyer, our group made a survey about covid-19, for which we
collected data in Italy. The collected data got cleaned, so every entry has no NaN value and is collectively completely useable.

we use multiple sources of covid-related surveys to back up our newly collected informations, checking if they contradict or complement for 
validation purposes.

<iframe width="740" height="409" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Sdiq5FiovWs" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
source.71342645: # Learning and Teaching Experiance under Covid-19
source.2b642f97:
# Recommendations for Exams

The traditional way of asking questions is not up to date with open-book or zoom oral exams.
Solution: A "real world" simulation such as a more complex task that comes close to the normal daily routine of the later work.
For IT, this would be a Scrum sprint including documentation, with small stones that lie between the student and the solution. Factors such as how well the student was able to find a solution on the web and apply/rewrite it play a role here.
how good was his handling with common tools.
an exam would then simulate, for example, a 4h working day, where the professor as head of department clarifies framework conditions for his students, without presenting solutions. Independent work, helping oneself, applying and recognizing mistakes/solutions/unnecessary info are encouraged.

This simulation can take place "live" in the university, with barriers. Intercom or similar. Or online via zoom/mail + pdf. Whichever suits the student better.
source.ff2a9b4b: Other: Biotech, Data Science / Business Analytics,
source.f4a1ee59:
**1	I’m finding it hard to cope with the Corona-enforced changes occurring in my life. **

Evaluation: 80 people find it difficult to cope with the life changes forced by Corona.

Problem: For 72% of respondents, the pandemic has had an enormous impact on their daily lives, with radical changes to their daily lives and studies.

Assistance/Recommendation/Solution: Universities can assist their students in this regard with open and transparent communication, such as education and advice.  Another approach would be to offer educational and psychological help.



**2	My stress level has increased during the Corona semester(s).**

Evaluation : 87 people think that the Corona Semester has increased their stress level.
 
Problem: Since Covid-19 broke out, many students are more stressed than usual.
 
Help/Recommendation/Solution: To find out what causes students to have higher stress levels than usual, the university could start a survey to determine what causes it. Resulting from this data, universities could address the exact issues and develop solution plans.
If the evaluation shows that most students are struggling with the transition to e-learning. As a result, the university could organize many information seminars for the students to facilitate this transition. 


[Results](https://www.jmir.org/2020/9/e21279): Of the 195 students, 138 (71%) indicated increased stress and anxiety due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Multiple stressors were identified that contributed to the increased levels of stress, anxiety, and depressive thoughts among students. These included fear and worry about their own health and of their loved ones (177/195, 91% reported negative impacts of the pandemic), difficulty in concentrating (173/195, 89%), disruptions to sleeping patterns (168/195, 86%), decreased social interactions due to physical distancing (167/195, 86%), and increased concerns on academic performance (159/195, 82%). 

Conclusions: Due to the long-lasting pandemic situation and onerous measures such as lockdown and stay-at-home orders, the COVID-19 pandemic brings negative impacts on higher education. The findings of our study highlight the urgent need to develop interventions and preventive strategies to address the mental health of college students.


**6    I fear the consequences the pandemic might have for me or family/close friends (e.g. unemployment, loss of income, decline in mental stability).**

Analysis: 88 out of 110 respondents stated that they feared the consequences of the pandemic. For themselves and their families.

Problem: Many students are worried about the future. Be it financially, professionally or psychologically.

Help/Recommendation/Solution: One solution would be to waive the students' tuition fees for the pandemic period. This would reduce financial worries, as many students have lost their jobs due to the pandemic and therefore have an income to pay rent and bills.
 It is not easy to concentrate on studying when you have to worry about how to pay the rent.  
 
 
 **7   I fear the consequences the pandemic might have for the economy (e.g. jobs, income, stress, social unrest).**


Evaluation: 90% of respondents fear the consequences that the pandemic could have for the economy. In this evaluation it is confirmed again that also the students have large concerns about the economic future. The universities, lecturers as well as the students must suffer from the consequences of the pandemic.

Problem: Students and lecturers fear for their jobs and income, by the pandemic and its consequences, many had to go into short-time work or have even lost the job.
Students fear that they will not get a job after graduation and thus slip into unemployment. 
The financial worry hits many students, because many work on the side to come over the rounds and from the consequences of the pandemic many have lost their jobs. 
A large part of the students is financially supported by the parents but also the parents feel the consequences of the pandemic, they have financial losses or no income at all.

Assistance/Recommendation/Solution:  In this problem the universities can counteract little, that some come by the consequences of the pandemic itself in financial bottlenecks.
